docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Pakistan's Welcome Gestures'' (editorial, Jan. 3):     I agree that we should appreciate any steps taken by Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan ''to reduce the threat of war'' with neighboring India. However, your suggestion t...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Pakistan's Welcome Gestures'' (editorial, Jan. 3): I agree that we should appreciate any steps taken by Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan ''to reduce the threat of war'' with neighboring India. However, your suggestion that what India has been trying to crush for more than a decade now is ''the aspirations among Kashmiris for independence or even greater self-government'' is misleading. What was started as a movement for independence or autonomy by a few Kashmiris has long since been taken over by Pakistani-sponsored terrorist groups. Also, evidence has emerged that many of the terrorists are linked to Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda.

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Nicholas D. Kristof (''The Boomerang Syndrome,'' column, April 2) argues that for a democratic government like Israel's, a military solution is doomed to fail against insurgents.    But consider: Is the supply of terrorists drive...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof (''The Boomerang Syndrome,'' column, April 2) argues that for a democratic government like Israel's, a military solution is doomed to fail against insurgents. But consider: Is the supply of terrorists driven more by growing Palestinian anger in response to Israeli actions or instead by the growing effectiveness of the terror tool?
docs.abstract: Rafael Harpaz letter says that Palestinian leaders differ only on best strategy for destruction of Jewish state, so that it makes no sense for Israel to rationally negotiate for its own destruction

headline.main: In the Mideast, A Widening Divide

docs.snippet: BELINKIE-Milton H. Connecticut's Superior Court Judge Milton H. Belinkie, 89, died January 29. He worked until the end and was predeceased by his wife Helen Jiler Belinkie, award-winning cookbook author. A graduate of Yale and Columbia Law schools...
docs.lead_paragraph: BELINKIE-Milton H. Connecticut's Superior Court Judge Milton H. Belinkie, 89, died January 29. He worked until the end and was predeceased by his wife Helen Jiler Belinkie, award-winning cookbook author. A graduate of Yale and Columbia Law schools, he did secret duty in WWII and gained notoriety for capturing Tokyo Rose, but refused to testify after the war. Milton loved poetry, Shakespeare, music, and played the violin in a symphony. He won trophies in tennis, squash, handball and played semi-pro baseball with a batting average of .422. He is survived by his daughter, actress, Carrie Jiler Belinkie, one brother and four sisters. He was loved by many and will be missed by all.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELINKIE, MILTON H.

docs.snippet: Anglo American, the metals and mining giant, said its Mondi International paper subsidiary began an unsolicited cash bid for the French packaging company, Rochette, valuing the French company at about 298 million euros ($270 million). Anglo has be...
docs.lead_paragraph: Anglo American, the metals and mining giant, said its Mondi International paper subsidiary began an unsolicited cash bid for the French packaging company, Rochette, valuing the French company at about 298 million euros ($270 million). Anglo has been seeking to move away from its South African roots since it moved its headquarters to London in 1999. The offer for Rochette, of 11.6 euros a share, could start a bidding war since Saica of Spain bought 22 percent of Rochette in late December for 10.9 euros a share. Anglo American's bid represented an 18 percent premium on Rochette's closing price last Friday. Anglo American's shares in London rose as much as 4.4 percent, to 1,087 pence. In addition to Rochette's shares, Anglo American also offered about 60 million euros, or $54 million, for Rochette's convertible bonds. Alan Cowell (NYT)
docs.abstract: Anglo American's Mondi International paper subsidiary begins unsolicited cash bid for French packaging company, Rochette, valuing company at about 298 million euros ($270 million) or 11.6 euros per share; offer could start bidding war since Saica of Spain bought 22 percent of Rochette in late December for 10.9 euros a share; Anglo American also offers about 60 million euros, or $54 million, for Rochette's convertible bonds (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tax Ruling Hurts I.R.S. A federal appeals court ruling in a case involving Compaq Computer will make it much more difficult for the Internal Revenue Service to demolish many corporate tax shelters, tax experts say. PAGE C1 Mandela Alters War Support Nelson Mandela, who was criticized by some in South Africa for strongly supporting the American-led campaign against terrorism, said his view ''may have been one-sided and overstated.'' PAGE A15
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The Enron debacle is the logical culmination of a system that increasingly favors corporate management over shareholders (''Enron Buffed Image to a Shine Even as It Rotted From Within,'' front page, Feb. 10).     There have been ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Enron debacle is the logical culmination of a system that increasingly favors corporate management over shareholders (''Enron Buffed Image to a Shine Even as It Rotted From Within,'' front page, Feb. 10). There have been past signs of trouble brewing, like the stratospheric rise in executive salaries and stock options. It should come as no surprise that something resembling a Rube Goldberg contraption would be constructed by managers whose frenzied desire to enrich themselves exceeded their capacity to do so ethically or sensibly.
docs.abstract: Letter from David Katcoff says Enron debacle is logical culmination of system that increasingly favors corporate management over shareholders

headline.main: Let's Make Enron a Turning Point

docs.snippet: An Islamic cleric who was praised by Al Qaeda and censured by the Saudi government, Sheik Hammoud bin Oqla al-Shoeiby, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 77.    Sheik al-Shoeiby rose to become a leading Islamic scholar in Saudi Arabia. His st...
docs.lead_paragraph: An Islamic cleric who was praised by Al Qaeda and censured by the Saudi government, Sheik Hammoud bin Oqla al-Shoeiby, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 77. Sheik al-Shoeiby rose to become a leading Islamic scholar in Saudi Arabia. His students included the country's mufti, the current minister of justice and a former Islamic affairs minister.
docs.abstract: Sheik Hammoud bin Oqla al-Shoeiby, Islamic cleric who was praised by Al Qaeda and censured by Saudi government, dies at age 77 (S)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    It's worth noting that crisis played a key role in the inception of many ancient Greek plays. Sophocles' ''Oedipus Tyrannus'' took its cue from the devastating plague that struck Athens in the early years of the Peloponnesian War...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It's worth noting that crisis played a key role in the inception of many ancient Greek plays. Sophocles' ''Oedipus Tyrannus'' took its cue from the devastating plague that struck Athens in the early years of the Peloponnesian War; Aeschylus' ''Oresteia'' from controversy over changes that had recently been made in Athens' Court of the Areopagus. The dire straits in which Athens found itself after the disastrous defeat of its Sicilian expedition provided the backdrop for both Euripides' ''Helen'' that year and Aristophanes' ''Lysistrata'' the following year.
docs.abstract: David H Porter letter on Anne Midgette's March 3 article recalls that many ancient Greek plays focused on local crises
